H E A L T H L A W S.

Code of Alabama 1907, Volume 1,
As Amended by Act of Legislature, No. 658,

SECTION 702. The State Board of Health shall
have authority and jurisdiction -

(6) to adopt and promulgate rules and regulations
providing proper methods and details for adminis-
tering the health and sanitary laws of the State,
which rules and regulations shall have the force
and effect of law and shall be executed and en-
forced by the same courts, bodies, officials, agents
and employees as in the case of health laws; and
any person knowingly, violating or failing or re-
fusing to obey or comply with, any such rule or
regulation shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and
shall be punished in accordance with the provisions
of section 7073 of this Code; and if the violation
or failure is a continuing one each day's viola-
tion or failure shall constitute a separate offence
and be punishable accordingly.

7073. Any person violating any of the provisions
of Article 1, of Chapter 22 of this Code, relating

or, and, upon conviction, shall be fined not less
than five nor more than one hundred dollars, unless
otherwise expressly provided for.
REGULATIONS GOVERNING THE IMPOUNDING OF WATERS.

In order to prevent an increase in the prevalence of
malaria and to avoid the formation of foci of endemic
malaria by the impounding of waters, under and by vir-
tue of authority vested in it by the Legislature of
Alabama (Amended Acts, 1919), the State Board of Health
does hereby promulgate and publish the following rules
and regulations governing the impounding of waters or
damming of water courses in the State of Alabama.

SECTION 1. Any person, firm, corporation, county, or
municipality desiring to impound water for any purpose
whatever, such person or collection of persons who,
propose to raise the level of a previously existing
pond by the elevation of the top of the dam, other than
for supplying water to domestic animals, shall, prior
to the iniation of any construction activities, make
application to the State Board of Health for, and ob-
tain from it, a preliminary permit for the impounding of
such water.

SECTION 2. Such application for a preliminary per-
mit shall be made in writing in the name of the person,
firm, corporation, county, or municipality making appli-
cation, and shall be accompanied by a description of
the proposed project, its purpose, and its exact loca-
tion; also by an accurate plat of the area to be affect-
ed, showing particularly the maximum and minimum water
levels.

SECTION 3. Such a temporary permit for the inaugura-
tion of initial construction shall be issued by the
State Board of Health when the following rules and regula-
tions, or modifications thereof, have been made to apply
to the said project.

3-a. In the area to be occupied by the Reser-
voir, its branches, bights, and indentations, all brush,
trees, undergrowth, logs, stumps, and similar objects,
which, if not removed, would float or collect flotage
on the surface of the impounded water, and all of the above
material that is lying on the ground or remaining in origi-
nal or new position, which would probably cause collection
of flotage to gather, and this constitute conditions favor-
able to the protection of larvae of mosquitoes capable of
conveying malaria, shall be removed, burned, or otherwise
satisfactorily disposed of, prior to the impounding of the
water.

NOTE: The above does not include grass, vegetation, brush,
trees, stumps, etc., which will be premanently and com-
pletely submerged at time of low water and which are, there-
fore, not of sanitary importance.

3-b. In the area to be occupied by the Reser-
voir, its branches, bights, and indentations, all brush,
trees, and undergrowth which would pierce the surface
at low water level shall be cut off at least one foot
- 3 -
below such low water level, to prevent the collec-
tion and anchorage of any possible flotage, rafts,
etc.

3-c. The shore line of the reservoir, its
branches, bights, and indentations, from minimum low
water level to a line 25 feet horizontally beyond
maximum high water level, shall be cleared of all
brush, trees, undergrowth, and the like, so as to
prevent the collection of drift and flotage along
the shore.

3-d. All pine trees within an area circum-
scribed by a line 50 feet inland from the maximum
high water level of the reservoir, its branches,
bights, and indentations, shall be ringed and deaden-
ed at the time of initial construction on the pro-
ject, so as to prevent the falling into the water
of pine tags, collections of which provide a favor-
able breeding place for Anopheline larvae.

3-e. Hatcheries for the propagation of Gam-
busia Affinis (top minnows) in sufficient numbers
to stock the reservoir, its branches, bights, and
indentations for effective mosquito control, shall
be provided at the time of initial construction on
the project, in accordance with definite written in-
structions from the State Board of Health.

3-f. All depressions which will be filled
with water from the reservoir, its branches, bights,
or indentations at time of maximum water level, in
which water will be retained at lower stages of the
water level, thus forming separate pools, shall be
connected with the normal body of the reservoir, or
any of its branches, bights, or indentations, with
a ditch or culvert which will permit complete drain-
age and the entrance of top-feeding minnows.

NOTE: Such places are generally few in number, but
are of importance in mosquito production.

3-g. All persons making application for em-
ployment on the construction of the project shall
be subjected to clinical or microscopic diagnostic
examination (or both) for malaria, and no person
giving a positive diagnosis, clinical or microscopic,
shall be employed anywhere on the project.

Such other measures to prevent the intro-
duction of malaria or other communicable diseases
into the project area, and the territory adjacent
thereto, as shall be directed by the State Board of
Health from time to time, shall be adopted and put
into effect.

SECTION 4. A preliminary permit for the impounding
of water having been granted by the State Board of
Health, and construction work on the project begun,
- 5 -
a representative of the State Board of Health
shall make inspections of the project from time
to time, and as requested by the permit holder,
and the State Board of Health shall approve in
writing of that portion of the work as is out-
lined in Section 3 of the Regulations which has
been satisfactorily completed.

As the said representative of the State
Board of Health determines that the preliminary
permit holder is complying with the provisions of
Section 3-a of these Regulations, and as it shall
appear that the preliminary permit holder has com-
plied with the provisions of Section 3-b of these
Regulations, the permit holder may thereupon pro-
ceed gradually, as authorized by written approval
from the State Board of Health, with the impound-
ing of water to a level specified by said represen-
tative of the Board of Health, and, when it shall
appear that the permit holder has complied with the
Regulations to the satisfaction of the Board, said
Board of Health shall certify such fact to the
permit holder in writing, and the permit holder may
thereupon proceed with the impounding of water to
a maximum high water level.

SECTION 5. The State Board of Health shall there-
upon issue a finalppermit for the maintenance of an
impounding project by said applicant, the validity
of said permit being contingent upon the observance
- 6 -
of the following regulations:

5-a During the mosquito breeding season the
permit holder shall regularly and frequently
remove all flotage and floating debris in the
reservoir, its branches, bights, and indenta-
tions, which are likely to harbor mosquito
larvae.

5-b Prompt and proper measures shall be taken
to prevent the growth of cat-tails, bulrushes,
and other aquatic or semi-aquatic vegetation
which offers protection of mosquito larvae from
their fish enemies.

5-c Newly created impounded waters shall not
be stocked with game fish without written permis-
sion from the State Board of Health.

No fishing in the impounded water, between
April 1st and November 1st, shall be permitted
for a period of three years after impounding, un-
less a permit is granted in writing from the State
Board of Health.

5-d After the water has been impounded, the
State Board of Health shall from time to time
make such inspections of the impounded waters
and adjacent areas as are deemed essential; and any
conditions found on the impounded water project that
are, or may
- 7 -
be, detrimental to public health, or are likely
to cause an increase of malaria, shall be modi-
fied by the permit holder so as to be satisfac-
tory to the State Board of Health.

5-e. These regulations shall govern any
change in water level and as soon as any pro-
posed changes affecting the maximum water eleva-
tion are contemplated, the State Board of Health
shall be notified in writing.

SECTION 6. Failure to comply with the provision
of any section of sub-section of these Regulations
shall constitute a violation thereof, and shall con-
stitute, according to Section 7073 of the Code of
Alabama, a misdemeanor, punishable as provided in
that Section.
DETAILED EXPLANATION AND INTERPRETATION.
Section-by-Section.
SECTION 1. --Self-explanatory.

SECTION 2. Irrespective of its extent, an impound-
ing project should be predicated on accurate data, and
such of this data as is of value in determining any
of the factors affecting mosquito-breeding should be
furnished to the State Board of Health, for informa-
tion and for purposes of record.
SECTION 3-a --Self-explanatory.
SECTION 3-b --Self-explanatory.

SECTION 3-c. The absence of permanent obstructions
near the water line permits of wave action on the
shore which is unfavorable to mosquito breeding. The
dam should be designed so that flash-boards will not
be needed nor used for any other purpose than the
stranding of floating logs, etc., on the shore during
winter months. During the mosquito-breeding season,
pronounced fluctuations of the water level may be,
or may be made to be, a controlling factor in breed-
ing. When the water level is varied at ten-day
intervals, a 24-inch fluctuation on steep slopes and
a 48-inch fluctuation on flat slopes, will make pro-
lific breeding improbable. Changes in water level
tend to prevent rank growth of aquatic plants and
aid fish enemies (Gambusia Affinis) in reaching the
mosquito larvae or flush the larvae within reach of
- 2 -
the fish. It is usually necessary to clear only
stranding places of low slope. Even here trees
25 feet or more apart are not objectionable.
SECTION 3-d --Self-explanatory.

SECTION 3-e. The size of the hatchery ponds should
be not less than 20 by 30 feet. These ponds should
contain a large area of shallow water, but in order
to prevent them from drying up in a brief space of
time, it appears advisable to provide a pit near the
center, of a depth of 3 or 4 feet, or more except
where the sub-stratum is porous. It is advisable to
maintain the water at a fairly constant level, but
the deep pit would serve to carry some of the fish
through a period of emergency; i.e., drought, or ex-
tremely cold weather.

The hatcheries should be constructed either in
areas already cleared or the woods should be cut back,
permitting a maximum of sunshine. This will stimulate
the growth of green plants (algae, etc.) and is es-
pecially agreeable to Gambusia.

Flowing water is not necessary or desirable, but,
if possible means for maintaining a fairly constant
water level should be provided. This can often be
done by making a connection between the pond and a
nearby creek with a water pipe equipped with a valve,
or perhaps by means of a connecting ditch provided with
a gate.

As soon as the ponds are completed and filled
with water, whether stocked with fish or not, a quan-
- 3 -
tity of green filamentous algae or pond scum
should be placed in the ponds. The lot of algae
transferred may die, but the spores from it will
probably start new plants. The scums should be
transferred in buckets or other waterproof con-
tainers without permitting the water in which they
are found to drain from them. In this way some of
the small animal life among the scums, too, will
be transferred and may establish themselves in the
new ponds. (Gambusia is primarily carnivorous, but
it also at times eats algae). A good growth of
algae in a pond attracts small animal life, and
such ponds are usually good Gambusia “hatcheries”.

A quantity of loose brush should also be placed
in the hatcheries, to provide small patches of shade,
attachment for the algae, and resting places for
small animal life.

The fish are taken most conveniently by the
use off a small drag net made of a good grade of mos-
quito netting, or still better, of bobbinet. Where
negetation is dense such a net cannot be operated,
and then a dip net, made of the same material, can
be used. The fish should be handled gently when
caught, allowing them to be exposed to the air the
shortest time necessary to make the transfer. It is
preferable never to handle the fish with the hands.
When a “clean catch” cannot be made and the fish can-
not be transferred to the container with the net in
- 4 -
which they were taken, it is advisable to leave
the net with fish in the edge of the water, sort-
ing and transferring the catch with a small hand
net.

If artificial feeding is found necessary (and
it probably will be for a few months at least), corn
bread, and fresh minced meat or fish may be provided.
It must be remembered, however, that a minnow is
small and cannot consume a large amount of food, and
it is not advantageous to provide more food than is
consumed before it decomposes. About two or three
feedings a week are sufficient.

The number, location, and degree of stocking, and
other directions concerning hatcheries will be speci-
fied or furnished, after inspection of the project, by
the State Board of Health.
SECTION 3-f. --Self-explanatory.

SECTION 3-g. It has frequently been determined that
serious outbreaks of malaria following the impound-
ing of waters have resulted from the introduction of
malaria from other sources into the ranks of construc-
tion organizations, leading to subsequent infection
of the mosquitoes and later the infection of the resi-
dents in the surrounding territory. This may be avoided
by medical examination of all applicants for employ-
ment, and the proper quinine treatment of the construc-
tion forces during their presence in the project area.
SECTION 4. --Self-explanatory.

SECTION 5-a. Fish cannot feed in flotage, and
their effectiveness in larvae destruction is reduced
in direct proportion to the flotage and debris pres-
ent.

SECTION 5-b. Game fish are particularly destructive
of Gambusia. Other types of fish, such as sun perch,
white perch, goggle-eyed perch, bream, calico bass, or
crappies, may be introduced without objection.

It has been found that well-stocked newly-formed
lakes become popular fishing grounds. The prevention
of fishing avoid the introduction of malaria by fisher-
men, who may hale from widely separated localities.
SECTION 5-d. -- Self-explanatory.
SECTION 6. -- Self-explanatory.
EXPLANATION AND INTERPRETATION OF STATE BOARD OF HEALTH
REGULATIONS GOVERNING THE IMPOUNDING OF WATERS.

Malaria fever is transmitted from person to per-
son by infected Anopheline mosquitoes. The suppression
of Anopheline breeding and the control of malaria carriers
are both essential measures in the prevention of malaria.

Past experience with impounded water projects
has given many well-known illustrations of rapid and pro-
nounced increases in the prevalence of malaria fever in
the territories adjacent thereto, because of more favor-
able conditions for the breeding of Anopheline mosquitoes
in great numbers.

The impounding of waters in river valleys is an
essential part of the proper development of the natural
resources of the State, and may be of marked benefit to
its present and future citizens. It is believed such in-
dustrial progress can be made, however, without rendering
considerable areas adjacent to such projects malarial and
unhealthful, at relatively slight additional expense.

Water power developments of the past, with the
resultant increases of malaria, in some instances of a
more pernicious type than previously obtained, have led
the State Board of Health to investigate such outbreaks
and to make scientific studies of the relation of newly
impounded waters to the increase and prevalence of malaria
in contiguous territory.

Among other facts that developed were the fol-
lowing, which have also been found to hold true in general
in other southern states where malaria prevails:
(1) When large bodies of water are impounded,
several years are required for nature to bring the
newly formed pond under such biological control con-
ditions as are found in old lakes or ponds, whether
natural or artificial.
(2) The production of conditions favorable or
unfavorable to the marked increase of malaria-bear-
ing mosquitoes is dependent upon the following fac-
tors:
(a) The topography of the basin affected.
(b) The shape of the contour of the shore
line.
(c) The species and number of trees, and
the character of brush and vegetation, es-
pecially that near or adjacent to and above
and below the high and low water flow lines.
(d) The exposure of the lake surface to
wind action.
(e) The frequency of strong wind in all in-
lets of the lake, in summer and in autumn
seasons.
(f) The frequency of heavy storms.
(g) The character of aquatic and semi-
aquatic growth in the lake and on its
rain-shed.
(h) The amounts of flotage and debris
carried by the streams feeding the lake.
(i) The natural fluctuations of water level-
seasonal, weekly or daily.
(j) The number and distribution of natural
enemies of mosquito larvae.
- 3 -
(k) Other variable factors.
(3) Under normal conditions in natura many
aquatic insects have aquatic enemies that prey on them
to the extent of materially decreasing their numbers.
The mosquito, in its early stage of development, is ex-
clusively aquatic and is preyed upon by various insects
and certain species of fish. Some species of fish not
only destroy very few larvae, but they sometimes almost
eliminate the mosquito-destroying kind of fish. They
also may limit the scope of action of those minnows which
prefer mosquito-larvae to other food and insects. When
water is freshly impounded, the ratio of fish that pre-
fer Anopheles-larvae as a food to the mosquito-larvae
supply is often very low, or below what will probably
be true several years or more later. This has been ob-
served to be the general rule in the upper portions of
arms and indentations, or long bights, of impounded
lakes. Also, if no precautionary measures (or unsatis-
factory precautionary measures) are undertaken, there
will generally be very much more protection afforded to
the mosquito-larvae during the early years of the life
of the artificial pond than is commonly found in older
ponds or lakes, whether natural or man-made, and, con-
sequently, their natural enemies will have difficulty
in reaching them.
(4) The particular places in newly formed lakes
or ponds where Anopheles-larvae frequently are to be
- 4 -
found in relatively large numbers are:
(a) In flotage and collections of flotage.
This if often composed of leaved, pine need-
les, small sticks, branches of trees, logs,
pieces of bark, etc., and some of it is some-
times covered with green algae. Anopheles-
larvae are also often found in numbers among
collections of aquatic of semi-aquatic plants,
especially so if certain algae are present.
(b) Clinging to isolated pieces of bark or
other drift when against or close to abrupt
banks in deep water, when wind and wave ac-
tion are or have been absent or light.
(c) At the upper ends (say the upper third)
of inlets of the pond or lake and their
branches, more so when relatively wind-shaded,
or in the absence of sufficiently severe wave
action.
(d) In shallow waters not affected by marked
fluctuation of water level or strong wave
action, in the absence of small mosquito de-
stroying fish; more frequently when certain
algae are present.
(5) When the production of Anopheles quadri-
maculatus is prolific over a considerable sized breed-
ing area, such as in an impounded water project con-
taining much flotage, overgrown banks with vegetation
hanging over into the water, collections of aquatic
plants, and absence of mosquito-destroying minnows,
etc., then the adult mosquitoes of this kind emerging
from the production area may be found at residences
and stables a mile distant from such a breeding area.
Under conditions similar to that outlined they have
not yet been found to travel to buildings 1 1/4 or 1 1/2
miles or more distant from their source. In the in-
vestigation of this subject it was generally found that
where the production of adult Anopheles quadrimaculatus
- 5 -
was less prolific, the adults were absent from
houses about a mile or more distant from the
production area.

In view of the vast undeveloped water
power in Alabama and because of the certainty of
the development of a number of impounding pro-
jects in the near future, these Regulations Govern-
ing the Impounding of Waters have been adopted in
order to conserve the public health and to serve
as a guide to those who plan the impounding of
water.
